Gabriel "Gabi" Delgado-LÃƒÂ³pez (born 18 April 1958 in CÃƒÂ³rdoba, Andalusia, Spain), commonly known as Gabi Delgado, is a composer, lyricist and producer. He is best known as singer and co-founder, with Robert GÃƒÂ¶rl, of the electronic band Deutsch Amerikanische Freundschaft.
He formed D.A.F. with GÃƒÂ¶rl in 1978. In 1980, he moved to London, where he lived until D.A.F. first split in 1984. He then moved to ZÃƒÂ¼rich and released the solo album Mistress, which did not sell well in Germany but was top 20 in Japan,[2] then reuniting with GÃƒÂ¶rl to record the 1986 D.A.F. album 1st Step to Heaven.
In 1986 he moved to Berlin to become a DJ and organise house parties. He organized (with WestBam and Marc Gubler) the first house party in Germany. With Saba Komssa, he founded the techno-house labels Delkom Club Control, BMWW and Sunday Morning Berlin.[1][2]
In 1995 he founded, with Wotan Wilke MÃƒÂ¶hring, the band DAF/DOS, who recorded the album Allein, zu zweit, mit Telefon (Alone, As A Couple, With Telephone), with the singles "Ich glaub ich fick dich spÃƒÂ¤ter" ("I Think I'll Fuck You Later") and "ZurÃƒÂ¼ck nach Marzahn" ("Back to Marzahn"). In 2003, Delgado reunited again with GÃƒÂ¶rl for another D.A.F. album, FÃƒÂ¼nfzehn neue D.A.F-Lieder (Fifteen New D.A.F. Songs).
